 APPENDIX 4.8: AMBIENT AIR                            QUALITY MONITORING AND
   ANALYSIS - METHODOLOGY


 Calibrated Resptrable Dust Samplers (Ennrotech APi\1460) (wHh flow mte-rangmg bet\veen 1 2-1 -+5
 m3/rrun) \vere used for monttonng of RPt\[ & SP~L Gaseous samples were collected by tntegmted
 gas samplmg assembl\" (Ennrotech :\P1\[ -+11) A rapping pronded 10 the hopper of the $ampler was
 ut.J.hsed for samplIng of SO: and N()l(. \vlth proper flow controller and a How of 10 l/mm.
 Envlrorech Orgaruc Vapour Sampler (APM 850) and a chgm111mporred personal sampler Dragger
 Muluwarn II, were used for moruronng CO and He Pameulace Lead (as Pb) ,vas deterrruned from
 me glass rruero fibre filter papers used for RPi\l

 Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM) and Respirable Particulate Matter (RPM)

 RPM was collected on a glass fibre filter mounted on a Resptrable Dust Sampler (RDS). The sampler
 15 attached Wim a cyclone. .Atr enters a vertIcal cylmder Wlth a SWtrlmg (vortex) mouon and parndes
 larger man deSign cut-off (I.e. 10 um chameter) are collected Ltl a dust colieenon borde fixed under
 me cyclone, whereas parucles below 10 rrucrons are deposIted on me filter paper. RPM was
 calculated by raltmg the dIfference between me final .and mmal weights of the filter paper and
 dIVlding by the volume of atr sampled at STP conwttons. SPM was calculated by takIng .the
 dIfference between me final and Ltllo.al welghts of the dust coUeetton bottle plus filter paper and
 WVtd!ng by the volume of atr sampled at STP condltl.ons: \ .                                     ..


 Sulphur dioxide (SOz)

 SOz was sampled and analysed as per ModIfied West-Gaeke specrrophotometnc method SOz
collected 10 a scrubbmg solutlon of sodIUm tetrachloro mercurate (Iel\,!) and was allowed to react
WIth sulpharruc aod, foanaldehyde and then With pararosaniline Hydrochloride_ The absorbance of
the product red-Vlolet dye was measured usmg UV VlSlble Spectrophotometer at a wavelength of 560
nm. Concentratton of SOl was calculated by multlplymg the absorbance of the sample Wlm me
callbratton factor of the method and chv1d1Og by the volume of atr sampled (to STP conditlons).

Oxides of Nitrogen (NOx)

 NOx was sampled and analysed as per Jacob and Hochetser modIfied method. Nitrogen oXldes as
rutrogen choXlde were collected by bubbling au: through sod1um hydroXlde-sochum arserute solution
to form a stable solution of sodIum rutrlte. The ruente Ion produced durmg sampl1ng was deterrruned
spectrophotometncally (at S40 nm) by In1t1aang the reaction berween the e~posed absorbmg reagent
\V1th phosphonc aod, sulpharulrurude and N (I-naphthyl) erhylarrune chhydrochlonde. Concentranon
of NOx was calculated as descnbed 10 SO: measurement.

Carbon monoxide-(CO) & Hydrocarbons (HC)

Env1!otech APM 850 Orgaruc Vapour Samplers are used for CO & HC morutonng :\ known
volume of atr IS passed through an actt\"lIted charcoal rube at a constant flow rate (100-200 m1/rrun)
With rrurumum pressure drop (10-15 mm of Hg). Vola ole Orgaruc Compounds (Voes) are adsorbed
on the acuvated charcoal wruch IS Iacer desorbed/ extracted usmg a SUItable orgaruc soh-ene.

                                                                                            Fcbru:m- 2003
l"amd Nadu Rood S~c[()r Prol"CT                                        ·\ppclldu;~...   [0   Conmhdal"d E.\ Rcporr



Extracted/desorbed solvent IS used for quantIfymg the orgaruc compounds wlth the help of Gas
Chromatograph The tube deSigned IS suitable for samphng of orgaruc compounds (YOCs) 10 It
concentratIon range 1-2500 mg/m3 for a 50 htre of aIr sample and the upper hmlt IS based on the
sorptIve capaclty and guantIty of actlnted charcoaL Standard l\ISA tubes are used fo.r morutonng
carbon monOXide A measured "olume of mr IS passed at the flow rate of 100 to 200 ml/mm for 1 to
8 hours The colour change (yellow to green) In mruc:mng gel filled In the detector tubes IS matched
With the colour chart pro'"lded with detector rubes for finding out CO concemr:lt1on

Particulate Lead

 The exposed glass fibre ftlter papers were cut Into 5111,'111 pieces and to It 100 ml rusulled water and 10
ml rumc aCid were added and heated on a hot plate for -+-6 hours The clear solutIon obtaIned after
rugesuon was filtered and made upto 25 ml and were analysed on a Cheffilto AtoffilC Absorpoon
Spectrophotometer (AAS) employmg Lead Hollow Cathode Lamp. Concentraoon of lead was
calculated by takmg the result obtatned from :\.:\5 analYSIS and ru\,rung It With the yolume of au
sampled.

I\1Jcrometeorologlcal data of ambient temperature, relatlYe hUffilruty, and atmosphenc pressure were
recorded at hourly mtervals for the morutonng penod to compute the volume of lUI sampled at STP
conrunon.

                    APPENDIX 4.9: LAND USE MANAGEMENT ALONG THE
                                                                        EASTERN CORRIDOR


 Induced Development along Eastern Corridor ~The Issue

  The 332 km long Eastern Corndor between Nagapamnam and Tuuconn runs for a malor length
  wltlun 3--1- km of the coast. The corndor CUts across S rustnCtS (Nagapatunam, ThanJa\'\lr, T1IU\'arur,
  Pudukkomu, Ramanarhapuram and Tuuconn) The GoTN has declared most of the Taluks along the
  comdor (espeoally along the southern stretch of the corndor) as soclallr and econorrucallr bacbvard
  due to the low level of 10frastructure facilities and resource ll',adability The project has been
  conceived With an objective of connect1Og these bacbvard coastal villages With a better road and
  thereby enabltng an unprovemem 10 the SOClo-econorruc profile of the coastal population. As has
  been confirmed from the vanous c!JscusslOns WIth the road users, the de\relopment of dus road will
 not change the preference of the long c!Jstance road users between the [\vO major portS of Chennal
 and Tuoconn. The eXlsllng NH--I-5 I 45B will remrun the preferred rome as 1t IS not only shorrer but
 also is 9f a lugher standard, compared to the tmprovements suggested 10 th1s proJect. Though the
 tmprovements proposed lOvolve only the wIde rung of the eXlscmg highway, there IS a hkehhood of
 the proJect leadmg to opentng of the coastal regton to development. Trus has the potenoal of leadmg
 to land use succession along the road. The enme eastern coast, due to ItS sedunentary formauon has
 been susceptlble to tntruslon of seawater, leadmg to scaroty of potable water. The development of a
 two-lane lughway rrught tnduce other land uses, lOcluchqg w~ter 10tenslve 10dustrlal uses.

 Addressal of the Issue
 As part of the 10dependent reVlew, an effort has been made to proVlde a dt.rectton for land use
 planrung along the eastern corodor by Integrallng development wah resource avauability, factoong 10
enVlCOnmental concerns and thresholds along the eastern coast. Thts shall be rumed at (i) dt.reccmg
and raoonalJ.z.ing development along cntlca} areas and (u) Streamhrung development along non
cnoca! areas. The approach adopted 1O\rolved the followmg steps:
 I·       Evaluatton of the eXlscmg land use planrung approach
 II       Analyse the eXlsong land use charactenstlcs along the corndor
III:      Identtfy development trends and locations vulnerable to 10duced development
IV .     Assess the envu:orunental consrrrunts and potenttals for de\-e!opmenr
V .      Assess tnttlnSlC sUltablUty for speCific land uses

VII :    Fmal.tse mechantsms for tmplemencauon :lnd tmplemencaoon arrangements

Existing land use planning approach


Overview
The DlIectorate of Town and Country planrung IS entrusted With the mandate of plan rung the
development and use of rural and urban areas m the State of Tarrul Nadu. In accordance WIth the
proVlslons of the Tarrul Nadu Town and Counrry Planrung Act, 1971 The act pro\"ldes for the
notlficauon of any area ttl the state [0 be a regIOnal planrung area, local planrung aref! or a new town.

  r~mu N~t.lu RO;'ld ~cCtur PrOlect




 Tlus nooficaoon by the Government IS based on the populanon sIZe of the area, de\'elopment 

 potenua!s etc. Once the nooficanon 15 made, the respecove authonty IS constituted, wiuch regulates 

 the planrung and development of land use Wlthm the area of Junsd.!CtIon through preparaoon of 

 regtonal, master and development plans respeCtIvely. 

 The master plans are prepared for the urban areas and the local plan rung areas, wlule the regtonal 

 plans cater to noofied regtonal planrung areas/dlsmcts The master plan speClfies "land use zones" 

 and the Development Concrol Regulaoons for each of the land use zones \Vlthm dle planrung area, 

 wlule the regtonal pinns pronde gwdehncs on the manner In wluch the land 10 the regton shall be

 de\'elopment controls for these master plan areas IS under the dtrect putVlew of the DoT&CP In
 other areas, me Town PancharatS and village Panchayats take up the approval deClSIons. Though the

 formality. TIus 15 largely due to the fact that there IS no zorung or delmeatlon of land uses for the
 enure dlStoct outSIde the notIfied planrung areas. Furthermore, as per the 74th Amendment, wruch
 empowers the local muruclpal bodIes and Panchayats, the declSlons of the elected local boroes
 overode the executive deClsions.

 prOVISIons of the development controls under the proVISIOns' of the Master Plans. These Include the

comdors, proposals for any major acn\'lnes 10 the regton and the ltkely unpacrs that could result due

and SOClo-eCOnOmlC data of the project dtStncts proVided the baSIS for Idenufymg areas susceptible to
10duced development unpacts. These Include:

-Urban areas and frmge areas of major settlements;

-Small agncultural patches between settlements;

-Stretches around locatIons of cultural/ tounst/ecologtcalmterests;

 Overlay & Composite Suitability
 The thematic maps were o\'erlmd to Idennfy and dehneate areas rhat are sUItable for deyelopmenr
 TillS also enabled the Idennticanon of areas nor sUItable for resldennal, commerCial and mdusll'lal

 1Odl\'lduaJ swrablhty maps were O\Terlllld to work our a composIte o\Terlay. The compOSite sUltablhry
 Identlfpng areas sUitable/ unSUItable for [he differem land uses IS presemed 10 F.tgUre 4.9.9
 Based on rhe overlays and the composne swrablhry exerCise, rhe followmg 1l1ferences have been
 arnved ae:
-78 km of rhe comdor falls m rhe sahne blocks and hence no resldennal and commeroallanduses
can occur. HowC\>er, low-density commercmllanduses can occur.
-Degraded forests are presem along 34 kms of rhe coendor between Ramanarhapuram and Tutlconn
and anorher 1 km of the COrridor is close to rhe mangroves between Murhupet and Manora. No
activities should be allowed in rhese areas,
-51.5 km of rhe comdor IS m areas of lugh sabnity contem (>5 ppt) and rherefore, no resldennal or
commerCIal actlvioes can take place m thIs region. 

-Development controls to be exerCIsed for a stretch of 164.5 km (111cluslve of rhe sabne blocks, 

degraded forests and mangroves) to regui2te land use proltferanon. 

-In areas other than the mangroves, forests and tugh sahruty zones, which 111cludes a comdor stretch 

of 170 Km, non-water 111tenslve industries, low-density reSidential and commeroal uses would be 

SUItable.

 Notification of the Entire Coaslal Stretch as a Planning Area

The TamJ.l Nadu T&CP Act, 1971, (PronslOn 101) states "the Go"ernment may b)" nooficaoon 10
TN Go,'"!: Gazette, from tIme to tIme. declare their mtenoon to specIfy any area 10 the state to be a
planrung area". Once nonfied as a plan rung area, a land use plan for the area nonfied can be prepared
and the development contrOls unplemented 10 accordance WIth the plan provlSlons.
The nonficanon IS generally done for a defirute geographlcal or adrrurustracive boundary The
dehneaoon of a stnp of land along the road   ,,,"!ll
                                                 cut across dtfferent admuustranve boundanes Also,
dehneatmg such a planrung area would Involve depnvIng the local authonoes of then: eXlsong
powers. As a result, the operatIonahzanon of dus opnon was not considered pracncal. Also, the tlme
taken for notIficaoon and preparatIon of the developmenr plans IS enormous.
Therefore, dus opoon 15 not taken up for subsequent conslderanon.

Establishment of a Separate Authority for Monitoring Land Uses along the Coast

All the e.~Stmg departments, local authonoes and regulatory autho.anes do have then: own rules,
 regulaoons, laws, by-laws etc and are suffiCIent to take care of controlling and moruronng the
 development acnvuies. Therefore no changes are reqwred. Further, no guarantee IS there to the
 effect that such revised statutes will meet the reqwrements In full and Wlthout legal problems.
To address the weak hnk of effectIve enforcement mecharusms, an option can be to bong tntO bemg
an .lnsntutIonai mecharusm, which will 'oversee the dehvenes of the local bodtes and statutory
authonties pertatrung to dus proJect. The secretariat of such an tnsotuoon shall be a full tlme office
headed by an seruor revenue officer delegated With powers to take deoSlOOs on all land use
perrrusslOn related Issues along the corodor. He will be supported In hts activioes by the Heads of
such Local Bodies, the Heads of concerned Go,remment departments, the Dlstnct collectors and
other distnct level of£ioals of the departments. Tlus DIstrict level comnuttee will morutor the
functIorung of the agenoes undeX' tlus project and remedy the Sltuaoons wherever called for. BesJdes,
there shall anse a SIngle point morutonng of the project to ensure course-correcnons as needed and
complenon on tIme,
The authonry at present hes WIth se,-eral heads of department as the Department of Town and
Country Planrung, Department of Town Panchayats. Department of EnVIronment etc. Serong up
such an authonty for the project \vas not found acceptable to the pamcipants. Therefore dus optIon
15 nOt further elaborated

 Further DeJiberations on the Issue of Landuse Management
 The ISsue of landuse management along the Eastern Corridor was further chscussed with vanous
 levels of stakeholders> to ascertain thell" VIewS. A separate sesSion in the workshop was set aSide to
 exclusively dtscuss the ISsues relared to ianduse management. After adequate dellberatlons on the
ISSue it was decided by all partlopants to 11lstitute a study on the Chennai Cuddalore seeOOD of the
East Coast Road. The study would focus on the unplementatloa process, the rrustakes COmmItted
 theretn, the lessons lea.cnt and the present day s1tuatiOn. It would proVIde COtlcal11lputs to formulate
measures to concrol mduced development along the project road.
It was deoded that an external agencr would be [esponslble for formulanog the Terms of Reference
(TOR) of the srudy, whtch would be sent to the HD for 11lcorporaang melt suggestlons. The HD IS
now under the process of fioaJ..wng the TOR for the study. Adequate cost prOVISIOns has been
Incorporated In me Envltonmental Budget to 101tl3re the srudy.

Training Modules
The trauung programmes for land use management will be held at both the state and ruStrlC[ level.
Two state level tr3.Ul1llg sessIOns and three dlstrlc[ le\-el trauung sessIons (for each of the dtStrlcts
selected) have been proposed. Each trrunlng sessIOn will be of 3 days. The agency selected for
carrying out the study on the Chennru Cuddalore section of the East Coast Road will also be
responsible for orgaruzmg the tralrung seSSIOns.
At the state b-el the trauung sessIons WIll be orgarused for the seruor offiCIals from the follOWing
departments
-Htghwan Department
-Publtc \'\'orks Department, Ground water
-Du:ectorate of Town and Country Planrung
-Department of Flshenes
-Department of Tounsm
-Town Panchayat
E.1ght dtstnCts have been selected for the dtStrlCt level trauung programmes. The dtstncts selected are
Nagapattinam, TIuruvarur, ThanJavur, Pudukkottai, Ramanathapuram, Tuticonn, Cuddalore and
SlYaganga. The Eastern Comdor runs across the first SL"I: rustncts. Cuddalore has been selected as the
Chtdambaram bypass (a new road of 16.9 Km) IS proposed m It whtle the SlVaganga has been
selected because of Its proX11Illty to the Eastern Comdor. The field level offioals of the followmg
departments will attend the dtstnct level programmes:                                 .

-HIghways Department
-Pubhc \'Vorks Department, Ground water
-Town Panchayats
-Village Panchayats

The first sessIon of the state level traUllng programme can commence unmedtately after the
completion of the proposed study. After an mterval of three months the dtstnCt level programmes
can start at the concerned dtstncts. The next trauung sessIon at the central level can Ideally occur at
the start of the unplementaoon stage. Thts sessIon will analyze the feedbacks reCeived from the field
level offiCIals. The second and thu:d seSSlons a.t the dtstOct level can soon follow swt Wlth an Interval
of about three months

required. TIus has happened m many cases of the regton ~lOce the water· SOurce is not perenrual.

the reglOn as grazmg by cattle 15 maul reason for degtadanon. 

For monkeys, plantation of frwt speCIes in the RF can be suggested to prOVide shade, food and 

decrease theu movements along the corodor. 

For Morutor hzards no ffilt1gation IS pOSSIble as ther generally mOl-'e through crevices and holes m the 

ground, and only occasionally they come to the surface. 

The arumals someornes cross the road 10 search of food 10 summer. Regarding the presence of 

crocodiles at _-\ruukkan, It was told that these would be generally found m water. It prefers marshy 

places and It IS a rare phenomenon to observe crocodtle m terrestrial enV1!onmenc. Even though they 

occur it IS dlfficult to predlct the locatton of thelI occurrence Rather than crocodtles, snake 

mo\'ement IS more m the raln}, season. Pythons generally crosses the 10 the CalOr season to go to the

                          Appendix 6.2 (viii); Consultation with Salt Pan and Prawn Culture Owners

 The ob)ectwe of the meeang was to ha\'e detaued mformatlon on the process adopted for salt
 makIng and shnmp farmmg. Also It was to knO\'\i from the stakeholders, the Lkely unpacts or benefits

 cycles, capac1t1es and markeang a\'enues. Followmg are the proceechngs at the consultauons:

 Salt Pan Owners:

 One of the salt pan owners consulted at km 27.000 on TNRSP03, Tonch - De\1.patanam secaon                   IS

 owning 10 acres of sale pans and has been his familiy's trad.1Uonal occupanon for the past 3
 generaaons. No new salt pans have been opened m the r~cent past. The pernusslon for operatmg salt
 pans IS obtamed from the V AO. The salt pan IS bemg operated Wlth about 8 labourers.

 Ground water is the source of water. It IS pumped up froth open well. \Vater level from the ground IS
 below 6-7m. Water will be retained In the salt pans for 4 days, wluch IS filled LCllaally at 1W'.

The salt brokers come to the salt pans and buy the salt to sell It m nearby markets.

For the query whether there IS an, noticeable change 10 the salirury content, the response was that
the salt content has been mcreasl..C1g for the past 4 to 5 year. \Vater 15 obtained from a depth of about
20ft. The sah.ruty of ground water IS reported to be lugher than the salLCllty of seawater, It IS
menaoned that the With a sali.rury meter (urnt mentioned as degrees) when chpped I..C1 sea water It
shows between 3 to -+ degrees \vhere as the ground water obtamed sho\vs 12 urnts of salLCuty.

There are some patches,near Devtpamnam and Tu:uppalakkuch that have some fresh water reserves.
All other locaaons all YIeld salme water

Shrimp Farm Owners;

The shrunp farm owners are aware of the TNRSP and are satd to be eagecly w'amng for the project
LClltlatlOn.

The source of water for these shnmp farms IS sea water Itself. It IS bemg pumped from the sea and
 transported through the canals to the ponds. The quanaty of water used IS asked for and the
response was About 3 ft water depth will be mamtamed for 3 months over an area of 1 5 ha \~later
                                                                             /
\\o1.ll be replaced to bnng the sahrnt}f every week from abour 40°/0 to 30C!- o to make It conduc1\'e for

growth of shrunp No fresh water IS bemg used 10 tlus farm to further bnng down the sah.ruty levels

Regarchng the IOcrease 10 sahrucy levels for the past .to-50 rears tt was asked whether he found any

 Appendix 6.2 (ix): Consultation with Mr. Karunagaran, MSSRF, on Mangrove
                                                              Conservation

 Venue: ~I S SWamJOlHhan Research Foundanon.   ~ruthuper
 Date: 19 08 2002                                                       Time: 6 30 P:'-f
 Anendees:

 From LASA                                                               From MSSRF
 :'\Ir ::'aush Kr Damodara                                               ;"[r Karunlgaran. Site
 Coorchnaror
 :'-Ir R \"Iswanarhnn


 The objective of ehe meeting was to have a detaued mformanon on the conservatlon techruques of
 mangroves along the east coast. Smce the MSSRF IS acnve in the mangrove cooserv:mon at Palk
 Strate Ie was felt prudent to have first hand lOformanon from the experts. The Meenng started WIth a
 general Ultroducaon to vanous programs that have been undertakeo In the Palk Stralt Followmg are
 the detatled proceedmgs of the meenng

 The conservaoon procedure involves generaung awareness among the local people regardmg the
 utility of mangrove speCles, dangers of cleanng mangrove forests and also On the Income generaung
 opporturuues from the mangrove eco-systems.

 ~l1cro  plans for regeneration, conservauon and propagn,tlon of mangro,,-es will be prepared at the
 field level by the local people. One sample of the rrucro plan has been prepared and It has been the
 model for preparauon of further plan preparaaon.

Alternative hvelihood schemes for the people dependent on the mangroves tradloonally have been
deVlsed and traming will be gtven. It was Informed that: the trainmg will be generally gtven by
experose bwlt up Inhouse and some wnes Views of external consultants will be procured. Such
hvehhood schemes such as COlI maktng, fishing In the mangroves, shnmp seed preparatlon,
aquaculture m small scale etc will be encouraged.

Regardmg techruques/procedure for plantlng and conservmg mangro,,-es, the follOWIng lOformanon
was delivered.

It was told that the first step would be to generate awareness among people.

The hkely tmpacts the proJect was explamed and It was told that some pornon of the mangroves can
be adopted for conservatlon. ThIs would be as a compeosatlon for the effect caused by the project It
was explamed that the modahoes of Implementaoon would be worked out by the speClahSt agency to
wruch the [ask shall be aSSigned. The present ob,ecoye IS to know the pracucal techruques that can be
assessed for thelI tmplementability

It was explamed that the techruque to be chosen 15 dependent on the site charactensocs and shore
charactensucs. There are two techruques as Fish bone techruque and canal techruque.

The techruques were explatned with the help of deSIgns prepared by MSSRF for Palk ·Smut and
Adlramapatnam.

There are traditlonal fishing grounds m the Palk Stratt formed due to m[ersotlOn of 8 malor canals
Ulland In the north-south directIon.

The area tharhas to be de,,·eloped will be dIvIded Into a network of canals under both the cechruques.

be smaller canals dug connecong the higher \Vldth of canals. These canals of same luerarchy will not
be mterconnected to aV01d moyement of sea current In the same closed C!rCUlt. Dunng rugh ode
mundatton of the canals \vill rake place and will bnng along a lor of silt as well as fish seeds, shnmp

and that the sea '\-'ater IS not stagnant.

mangro,-es shall be planted at the le,-el of low ode. The roots of the mangrores so de,-eJoped \"ill be

                    Appendix 6.3 (xi): Discussion with ORO, TNRSP on R&R issues

 Date: 14.082002
 FromLASA
 ::'IIr. i\LKaalunurhu
 ;'\lr R Yishwanathan


 The purpose of the discussion with the ORO was to understand the mechanIsm to be adopted In
 unplememaoon of RAP The outcome of the diScussions IS presented below

 Resettlernent Site:

 Sorne of the SItes proposed for resettlernent are water bowes that belong to P\vD or the Pancha,at.
 As per the procedures the lands noufied as water bowes can be used only afrer arm-.ng at a I~Int
 agreernent by the P\XlD offiCIals, Revenue offiCIals and the PIU. If the P\VD objects to the
 acqUlslUon of the lands then these lands cannot be used.

 When asked about proposIng forestland for resettlement the DRO confirmed that none of the land
 Idenufied for resettlement fall under the Department of Forests. They may not be
 protected/reserved forests.

  After the SIte visIts along the Northern (omdor, the IER team Insisted on the need for reo
  exarnmatIon of the Sltes selected and caay out a pubhc consultatIons for sue selection. ORO
. rnenooned that follow up acoons have smce then beefl i.ru~ted by the PIU through the Land
  Acqwsition cell.                                         .

the project corrIdor was to carry out consultauons ' . .1th the PAPs and examine the suitability of the
resettlernent sItes. The RDO/TahsIldars deSIgnated to perforrn the duues of Collector will caay out
these acoVloes. It was suggested to the DRO that the consultaoon sessions WIth the cornrnuruty
should be documented.

POWERS TO MUNICIPAL COUNCILS AND PANCHAYAT BOARDS

~[uruC1pal Councus are competent to grant permtSSlon for the remoyal of sand. etc, from sources of
water supply vesred 10 chc:tn, onh" so far as such removal IS '1ecessary for me purposes of mrunt::urung
[hem In an effiCIent concitoon In all orner Clses. the\' shall obt:un the pre\'lous perrrussioo of the

the Collector suo moco permtrs the remo"al of rrunor rrunerals from sources of water-supply vested
10 the Muruclpal Co uncus. the Muruclpal Co uncus shall be prenously consulted so thar     melareer m!lT

have an opportumty of examIrung whether such a proposal will haye the effect of Interfeong with the
maintenance of property. Panchayats shall be simIlarly consulted In respect of water ways under their
control Removal of sand, etc" from the water \vays under the control of Ivluruclpal Councils or
Panchayars may be allowed free of charge for bonafide publIc purposes and not for sale or
commemal profit. No selgruorage fee shall be charged for the remo\'al of sand by the pubhc for
bonafide domestic or agrIcultural purposes but such removal shall be subject [0 the prevIous
appro\'nl of the Reyenue DlnslOnal Officer 10 rhe case of wateC\vays under the control of Mumclpnl
Councils and the Panch:lxat Vruon COmmIssioner concerned 10 the case of \vaterwa\,s under the

the selgruorage fee at the rates speCIfied In Appendix II to these rules shall be Charged

QUARRYING IN RESERVE FOREST

In the case of lands wruch ha\'e been constlruted as reseC\'ed forest under sectlon 16 of the TamIl
Nadu Forests Act, 1882 (TamIl Nadu Act V of 1882) all quarrpng and remont of turf and the earth'
by the public IS prolublted except 10 accordance with permIts granted under the Said Act- The Forest
Deparement      marallow other Deparrments of Government and local bodies to quarry 111 forest areas
and charge for the mateoal quarned. \'Vhen quarrymg perrruts or regular leases are granted to the
pubhc or to the Government Departments, Government owned Corporatlons or Comparues and
local borues, the matenal quamed shall be charged at the rates speofied 10 Appenrux II to these rules
or the lease amount and other charges shall be collected as the case may be, as prOVIded 10 these
rules. The procedures and conrutlons prescnbed 10 rules 3,7 and 8 of these rules, as the case may be,
shall be applIed to deal \'\,"lth these cases
VIOlation of these rules shall entail prosecution under rules 13 and 15 of the Forest rules framed
under sectlon 26 of the TamIl Nadu Forest Act, 1882 (TamIl Nadu Act V of 1882) ;

QUARRYING IN RESERVED LANDS

In the case of lands which have been notified as reserved lands under the rules Issued by the
Go,'ernment under secllon 26 of the TamIl Nadu Forest Act, 1882 (TamIl Nadu Act V of 1882), the
pubhc may be allowed to quarry prOVIded firstly that such quarrY10g shall not lOJure the growth of
any tree, secondly that lt may be prohlbued 10 any area for any speCial reasons' and thudly the
quarrymg shall be subject to the payment of selgruoragc fee or lease amount, as the case may be, as
speCIfied 10 these rules. The procedures and conrutlons presccbed 10 rules 3,7 and 8 of these rules, as
the case  mar  be, shall be applJed to deal w1th these cases
VIOlatlon of these rules shall emali prosecution under rules 13 and 15 of the Forest rules framed
under sectlOn 26 of the TamIl Nadu Forest Act, 1882 (TamIl Nadu Act V of 1882);

             the EIA Nonficatlon, 1994 wruch hSIS proJecls reqwnng EnVIronmental Cle::u:ance. Tlus nottficaoon
             replaced hem 21 of the Schedule and SIlted.

            land :lcqUlSltton. The saltenc features of dus cLrcular are glyen below

                                The Notification States.
                               "It is hereby clanfied that marginal land acquIsItion means land acquisition not exceedIng a total
                               Width of 20 meters on eIther Side of the existing alignment put together. Further, It IS also clanfied
                               that bypasses would be treated as stand alone projects and would require enVIronmental clearance
                               only If the cost of the project exceeds Rs 50 emres each.~                                 .. , .",

Natural Habitat Policy
As per the \,\'orld Bank OP 40-+, the comernwon of I1:ltural hablcats l ", hke ocher measures that
protect and enhance the ennronmenr, lS essential for long-term sustrun:1ble de\-e1opmem .A

sustainable deYClopmem has been adopred for the prOlect The mam fearures of Bank's Narum]
Habitats Pollc,' are outlrned 10 Box 3
In order to as~ess the potenoal of the project aCOYloes to poslU\'ely or negauvely affect the natural
resources, an assessment as been carned OUt as parr of the EL\ process. The srudy mcludes
Idenuficallon of (a) natural habitat Issues along the prOJcct road and speCial needs for narural habltat
consen-atlon, mcludmg the degree of threat ro tdenofied natural habmltS and (b) measures for
protectmg such areas.


                                             Box 3. MaIn features of the Bank's Natural Habitats Policy (OP 4.04)
            The policy on natural habitats contams two major proviSions with respect to biodIversity
           :conservation and EA. Firstly, it prohibits Bank involvement in projects, which involve Significant
           ,conversion or degradation of critical natural h~bitats. These include: existing protected areas and
            adjOIning or linked areas or resources (such '?S water sources) on which the protected areas
            depend: and sites' identified as meriting protection. Secondly. where natural habitats out-SIde.
            protected areas' are-, within a project's area of -.influence, the' project· must not convert them
            significantly unless:, ;;-1 :

(! r)      GULf OF i\f:\j\,,'.i \1\ BIOSPf'II~RE RE:-.ER\-E
The Gulf of l\Iannar Biosphere Resen-e IS a manne resen-e off the dlstrlcts of Ramanarhapuram and
TuttcODn_ The Resen--e compnses 11 Islands and, With a land area of 623 ha and seas shallower chan
.3 S fathoms on the landward Side of the Islands. The nearest among the 21lsiands, Kwyashult, hes at
a ruscance of about 7 km from the road upgrade The Gulf of [\Jannar IS the fuse Manne Biosphere
Resen:-e nor only 1fl Inwa, bur tn South and South-east ASIa. BIOphYSIcal uruqueness, econOmlC,
SOCial, cultural and sClenofic tmportance, nanonal and global sigruficance, and management
compaabthcy at the local and naaonal level, were used as the baSIS for selectlrlg the resen"e as a
poonty sIte (Gllif oj Alannar Alanagemenl Plan, Draft>. The Gulf of l\Iannar BIOsphere Reserve
composes 21 Islands, mostly of coral oOgln The manne resources supported by the BIO Reserve are
descobed below

Coral Reefs
The Islands are bullt of a calcareous framework of dead corals and coral reefs. There are
appcoXlnlareiy 120 species of coral belonglOg ro 33 genera associated WIth these reefs (Nee/aun/an,
199.)). The coral reefs support a Wide vanet)' of marine aruma1s, vegetatlon and a great ruverslty of
algae, sponges, and fish. The coral reefs are rapIdly deteooranng as a result of human Interference,
greater stir lOflow dr:urung from the mrunland. Wlnds blown sand and other causes
Coastal Wetlands
There are a Wide vanery of natural wetlands along the coast, mduding esruanes, salt marshes, ada!
flars and coastal lagoons Most of the wetlands offer ,"aluable habitat for bu-dl1fe Of partIcular
tmportance are the wetlands \'\I'lth mangroyes and the coastal lagoons '\.'II1th extenSIve vegetatlon. The
econorrucally vtable species of l-[;pltea, Gdldtdla, Gra,elana, StmhoJpermllm. l-[;'drodathllmJ, C/arhraIIlJ,
PaaJlta, and Call/erpa are well rusrnbured In the Gulf of l\lannar
Sea grasses
Seagrass are manne planes belonglOg to tWO monocorl'ledonous farru.hes, H.),aro.hanto!ca( and
Pot,;moget()ltauae. There are extensn-e seagrass beds along the coast) The seagrass beds are feerung
grounds for the dugong (DlIgM,g dllgon:y The,- are responsible for makll1g Park Bay and the Gulf of
Mann:u the most tmporrant areas In rhe regIOn for the Dugong The seagrass beds also pro\1de
feewng areas for all five speaes of manne turtles These are the Green (Chelonta m;-aaJ). Loggerhead
(Car~tta ,'Qrelfa), O\.tve RIdley (Ltplllo,heQ'J ollvaua), HawksbLlI (Eremo,heQ'J Imbncala) and Leacherback
(D~rmo,be!)'J ,orC/ua) Manr speCIes of crusrace:ms, molluscs, gastropods and fish are also known [Q
Inhabit the seagrass beds off the coasr. The seagrass commUlllues are also valuable habitat for
commercllll speCIes, parocularlr the green oger prawn. Pmaew umlJllAatuJ, wluch IS exrensr<.-ely
han"esced for the export market

Sea Cucumber

      (A)      Impact on Forest Land

      (B)        Impact on Reserved Forests along Northern Corridor

      The Project Road passes through Uus Resen'e Forest at two locaoons between Km 17.6 - 180
      (148.6) - 148.3 and Km 147.0-146'-+. The forest IS patchy because of human settlements (vlliages)
      Inside the forest at sf"eral places. Instances of arumal mo\"ement. especlalJy of spotted deer, across
      the road were also reported

      The Forest Department has constructed check dams U1 several places In dus forest to make It
      unnecessary for the deer to cross the road for water. But consultanons With Forest OffiClals have
      re\'ealed the fact that chances of such crossIngs are very remote.


      (II)       P.-\R\":\TH.-\i\L-\L-\1 RESER\"E FOREST - POLUR Cl·IENG.~\1 RO.-\D LINK

      Km 22.0 - 23 0, where Sn .A.mman and Ayyanar temples are slruated and where the road is closest to.
      the forest. Here, a Fi£'1Is bengha/ens/J tree (a sacred tree) is found on the northern SIde of the road, at a
      rustance of 3 meters from the edge of the road. On dus tree, many buds reSide dUIU1g the rught
      hours .-\t this locanon there are many monkeys crossmg the road often. Deer cross the road at dllS
      SHe from the forest to the southern cultn'ated area dunng the swnmer season when there 1S water
      scarcity 10 the forest area.

      Thus buds, monken and deer may be rurectly affected due to the proposed road upgrade. Further,
      U1creased nOlse fro~ illcreased traffic flO\vs ffilght rusrurb the arumals occurnng 10 the lOtenor forest
      area. In most locanons the roadSIde plants that \\'111 be affected by the road upgrade are common

                                                     Appendix 8.4: Cultural Properties Management Plan
--------------------~~-----
CULTURAL RESOURCES IN THE PROJECT CONTEXT

(A)          Religious Centres

(c)        Archaeological Monuments
Gangrukondacholapuram 15 a place of archaeologIcal Importance along the Northern Corndor
[fNRSP 01 (S)J. The temple strucrure IS located at Km 94.5 between Jayamkonadam to
Kumbakonam at a cUstance of 70 m from the centrelme of the eXlsrmg road. It was the capital of the
Cholas establIshed by RaJendra Chola I (1012 - 1044 AD). A temple erected at the SHe bespeaks the
unpenal dlgruty of Chola art and ",ctonous mood of the roral patron, after IDS successful campaIgns
IIIthe Deccan up to the Ganga Valley, earrung for hun; rus tltle "Gangat Kondan". The temple,
surular III style to the ThanJavur Temple. has a tower of 180 feet O\'er the sanctum sanctorum. The
flora and fauna of the area IS of no speaal sIgruficance, except for the Blue Rock PIgeon and the
Rose RlOged Parakeet that hye 10 the temple tower.
Along the Eastern Corodoc between Muthuper and KattumavacU (Km 26.0 -27.0) the Manora
Commemoraoon Tower IS located at a distance of about 1 Km from the road. It was bulle by KIng
SarO]I II III 1814. The monument IS protected by the Tamtl Nadu Stare Department of Archaeology
(d)        Sacred Groves

(/)       Along c.Jpgradatlon Corndor.r
In every village m Tamtl Nadu there IS a pond or tank Wlth a sh.rme on ltS banks (Kri.rhna and
Prabhakaran. 1997). Nearby IS a grove of trees, or perhaps a smgJe ancient tree. In many VIllages
along the Corodor, sacred groves l2 are obsen·ed. In most cases a temple/shnne 15 the central fearure
surrounded by number of trees. The trees at some places are Yery old and also consIdered sacred by
the local people. In other cases ponds/tanks are found 10 close "ICIOlty of the gro\'e Some faunal
speCIes local to the area and m a few cases some ffilgrarory a\1an species ha\'e been obsenred near
some of the gro,-es. The hst of sacred gro\'es along upgradatlon COrrIdors IS presented In Table 8 4.5.

CONSULTATION PROCESS

Commurury consultatlon was undertaken to make exphclt the soctal factors that remam behtnd the
unport:lnce of the SIte for the local people Also It was carned OUt to know the assoclated
soctal!lustoncal sigruficance to diSCUSSions with the local commurury and general obseC\'aoons of the
sues and structures. The consultaoon process tncludcs the soao-cultural an'alysls and speaficaily
addressed Issue of how the commurucy can best get benefit out of It. The consultanons \vere held at
local (commuruty) level. The obJectlve of the consultallon was to !Illrurruze the negatlve unpacts                   1tl

the project corrldor and thel! lnvol,'ement tn the enhancement process The process further trIed to
Idenll~'   md    assess all mllJor econO!IllC and soclOloglcal characteostlcs of the village               to   enable
effecoye plaruung and unplementaoon. Dunng the process efforts were made to ascertaUl the views
and preferences of the people. The consulraoon program Include the followmg:

MITIGATION / ENHANCEMENT DESIGNS

Ennronmental Enhancement has been referred to as the pOSH1\'e actions to be taken lip durmg the
Implementauon of the project for the benefit of the road uc;ers and the commumues 1tnng along the
ProJcct Corndor
The enhancements should be carned out \\'1[h the follO\vlng obJectl\'es
    To enhance the appeal and ennronmental qua1tty of the proJect comdor to            ltS U$\!r~


    To enhance \'Isual quahrr along the rugh\\'ay, and

    To generate good\vtll amongst the local commuruty towards the proJect, by the enhancement of
    common property resources
The northern corndor passes near many SHes of reh@ous, rustorlcal, and/or cultural sigruficance
Gang:ukondacholapuram IS a place of archaeologJcal unportance along the Jayamkondam to
Kumbakonam stretch The Archaeolol51ca1 Sut\-ey of India protects the monument Some of the
stretches are close t"l few sacred gro'-es. In most cases a temple/ shnne IS the central feature
surrounded by number of trees. The trees at some places aIe '-ery old and also conSIdered sacred by
the local people.
The eastern corndor passes near many sites of relIl51ous, historical, and/or cultural slgruficance
Between IVluthupet and Karruma\-aw (Km 26 0 - 27 0) the Manora Commemoration Tower IS
located at a wstance of about 1 Km from the road. like northern corndor dus stretch IS also close to
few sacred groves.

ENHANCEMENT GUIDELINES OF CULTURAL PROPERTIES

GlIide/illes for   Ellha!U~menl

   Appendix 8.5: Concepts and Interventions of Enhancements Proposed under
                                                                                                            TNRSP

ARULMIGU MARIAMMAN KOIL (DRG NO 2002/73121/ENV/01/01)

Chainage: 2/0


Stretch: Arcot to Arani

relocated The front of the temple would also be affected due to the wlderung of the road

contribute ~o the character of the road at the stretch The temple attracts masses from the local and
would defirutely benefit U1 terms of usage after enhancement.

contnbute to dus
